critique: This document, an executive order from Franklin D. Roosevelt, directs the Secretary of the Interior to take possession and operate coal mines facing labor disputes during World War II. It aims to ensure uninterrupted coal production for the war effort. The order emphasizes maintaining existing employment terms and conditions, utilizing federal agencies for support, and allowing existing management to continue functions where possible. Possession is to be terminated once productive efficiency is restored. The document reflects a strong assertion of executive power in a time of national crisis, prioritizing national security and war production over typical labor rights and economic freedoms.
